After seeing the Quadrocopter by Zaggo, I decided it was time to try printing Sublime's daunting propeller. The only way I could get it to print was vertically at 1.75 x original scale. I had to add a platform directly into the model in order to get the required stability to print the blades vertically. I also scaled the hub by an additional 5% so that the blades fit in snugly without all that bothersome sanding.
Print out two blades and a hub. Gently snap each blade from its circular platform. Snap blades into hub. Add 9 volt battery and a small DC motor for an instant fan.

i remixed the customizable ashtray from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:316440/ i just added an extinguisher to the center. works like a charm and makes the ashtray much more durable, because of less contact with hot ash. the exinguisher is conic to add more stability and prevent breaking off.
With an exinguisher in your ashtray you dont have to worry printing one out of PLA, especially because ABS is more addictive to fire and beeing burned. Also you dont have to worry about hazardous gases with PLA. Mine on the picture is made of white PLA and works just fine, no wear-off or burned spots are visible after ~150 uses.
edit: Updated SCAD and STL for better printablity; i made the outer bottom overhang less cliffy so that it prints better with PLA, even without a proper cooling
printed in white PLA with .5 nozzle in .3 layers with 25% infill @ 65mm/s on my delta-printer.

comments.text: These are quite awesome, I do however have to say that the center piece is only good if you print above 80% of actual size...  Unfortunately my printer can only go up to 77% of actual size so I'm working to have the extinguisher removed.  If it's possible, I'd love to connect with you to see if you'd be able to simply expand the extinguisher for small dimensions

title: i3v 10" Prusa Makerfarm X-Carriage Stock Style

description.text: I tried to match the stock style as closely as possibly.
I updated the file to have the "center gear cutout", but I'm not sure how accurate it is. It's a little larger than the stock carriage though, so it should work.

This is the precursor to a Bulldog Lite X-Carriage I'm working on to get the correct dimensions. The photos I took are of a version before this, this one has the bottom three cutouts if you choose to use two eccentric spacer mounts. OpenSCAD file is included
I think all measurements are 99% accurate, especially the screw holes. I added 0.5mm diameter to all holes to ensure they have room to easily place the bolts. You can adjust this in the OpenSCAD file if they are too loose. The extruder mount may extend about 1mm further than the original. Please leave any feedback in comments.

I printed this with a brim to prevent warping and I would suggest something like 30% infill.
The part should lie flat on the printer bed with the extruder mount pointing upwards. No supports are necessary.

Toaster simple autonomous vehicular design (by autonomous I mean "goes forward all by itself" not "navigates its surroundings all by itself"). You will need a DC motor a 9 volt battery and a 9 volt battery connector. Your motor probably won't snap into the motor holder unless it happens to be the PARSIMONIOUS & PETITE MOTOR from American Science & Surplus, but the design should be easy to modify to fit whatever you've got lying around (Yes, I know it's a 6 volt motor hardwired to a 9 volt battery-- trust me it won't blow up).

Print out two chassis-lengths,  one motor holder, two bumpers, three axels, four wheels and one each of the two gears. Snap bumpers and chassis-lengths together to form the frame. Push motor gear onto dc motor. Insert DC motor into motor holder with wires protruding out the back. Slide motor holder on one axel and motor-gear on another. Slide rear axel (the one with the gear on it) into the holes in the chassis-length farthest from the other two holes. Secure rear axel in place by snapping on wheels. Insert front axel and secure in place with remaining two wheels. Insert middle axel into square center holes in chassis. Glue center axel into place at both ends. Slide motor holder to center of axel and glue in place. Slide rear axel gear along rear axel until it lines up with motor gear and glue rear axel gear into place. You may also want to glue the wheels onto the axels, but if you do it will become permanently un-assembleable.

A low-poly gorilla

• Lorilla.stl is the whole guy
  • Lorilla-Parts.stl has the model split into two parts, which should print without support, and which you'll need to glue together
  • StackedCardLayerTemplate.pdf is the template to use if you want to 3D print Lo-Rilla by hand (this took me about 3 episodes of Star Trek: The Next Generation to cut and stick).
  • LaserCutting.dwg is for cutting out layers with a laser cutter or CNC router. It's based on a material thickness of 2.5mm.

If anyone wants to make it that way, I've added a PDF template for cutting out the layers; the cardboard I used was around 1/10" thick but the template has directions so you can scale it for whatever material you have handy.

An electric toothbrush rack designed to invert the brushes (which helps keep handles and chargers far less manky). Enough clearance has been left for the charger to be engaged in situ.  
I've inserted small, plastic bottles (with bases removed) into my rack -  which can be removed for cleaning - but these are not required for the rack to work.  
The rack pair can be attached to a backing plate, or directly to a wall. 2mm-diameter pilot holes have been included in the model. These will need to be drilled out (and perhaps countersunk) to work with your choice of screw.

title: Mendel90 Alternate Spool Holder v2 - Complete Overkill

description.text:
Apparently there is no real standardization in spool sizes. This vexes me.
I redesigned the spool holder to be much thinner. This also required the male/female brackets to be flipped and the female one now prints holes down.
It can support spools with inside widths of 52mm to outside widths of 107mm.

Again, i recognize that this is complete overkill, but I haven't found a spool that won't fit yet. Print the male and female parts twice and one dust filter. Note that the dust filter now clips to the top support of the male bracket and the bolt for the bearings to prevent the filament from rubbing on the threads. I used a 5/16" x 5" bolt since I couldn't find an M8 bolt long enough readily available.
The assembled order pictured is: H-PWBWPR--------RPWBBBBBBWPN-- B - 608 Bearing
W - Washer
P - Penny washer
N - Nylon lock nut
H - Bolt head
R - Printed bracket

comments.text: Works great!  Hopefully this is the last spool holder I'll need, I'm tired of messing around with them.

title: Lamp base with Arduino brain control

description.text: Customized Lamp base with LED ring, microphone, light sensor and temperature and humidity sensor.

Because i love this incredible lamp, i am trying to improved (if this is even possible...). So, i added a couple of things: -new lamp base holding a controllable LED ring
-Microphone in order to control the LEDs by snapping fingers (or shouting at it...up to you)
-Light sensor to control LEDs intensity (and for future automation)
-Temperature and humidity sensors (for future upgrade to adjust LED colors based on Temp and Humidity....kind of weather lamp) The lamp will go thru different modes by snapping fingers:
-candle light
-green
-blue
-red
-pink
-white
-mood lamp (will change slowly colors)
-off mode (no light that is...) I post there the below: -Google sketch of the lamp base without decoration. But, do not try to print it yet...i kind of screw up the top of the walls (they go close to zero thickness...it's a miracle i managed to print it..)
-Arduino sketch to control the LEDs
-STL of the inside LED "bulb" + LED ring holder
-STL of the Lamp base after tinkering it on Tinkercad Both the "final" lamp base and the bulb are availlable for modification on Tinkercad (search for Kyoxilbuzz). As you will see, the tinkercad includes the beautiful owl from satoshi (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29602). Things i will continue with this base lamp are:
-solving this thin wall thing for easier print
-make the base less basic. i have in mind of making a tree shape, and add more animals around it.
-make the electronics smaller to fit inside the base
-of course, making the flower to open automatically...as i really suck at mechanics, that might takes a while :)

comments.text: put a small motor inside to open and close the petals

description.text: Inspired by Roman Hegglin's terrific Tower of Pi, I cobbled up a little program that makes various types of towers of letters. The long, thin tower is Lincoln's Gettysburg Address.

Kudos to Roman Hegglin.

comments.text: your right support material is expensive, that is if you are using PVA ( about $120.00 aud) which I do have a roll but im using HIPS which is about the same as a roll of ABS or PLA.($40.00 AUD) .The d limonene I am also trying is as I said made from orange peel , basically it is a orange mineral terpintine. Only eats the HIPS support material and hopefully will leave my model intact and smooth. I'll lert you know the outcome , and if it doesn't work i'll be stuck with 30 litres of the stuff...........
comments.author: andmerr

comments.text:
hi cerberus333 this looks really good. I am about to buy a flashforge dual head printer and will give this one a go. i noticed in your comment that it was hard to get rid of the support material and thought that if you had a dual head printer that this tip might be good for you.
That's a support material called HIPS (high impact poly styrene) which can be used as the support. To get rid of the support theres a chemical called D Limonene (made out of orange peel) that will eat away the support material but leave your model whether its PLA or ABS clean.
comments.author: andmerr

comments.text:
Hi
I do know about the soluable filament for support option.
It is unfortunately expensive.
Personally I have seen more issues with dual extruders (knocking over prints in progress etc)
that I see them as a negative.
removal of support is not as bad as it used to be.
And I am not adverse to a 10 -15 minute clean-up on a model.
(in this case to get the lid to fit well emery board on each tine (3-5 strokes was plenty))
Generally I try to post a pic on the build plate showing the supports
and mention it in the description to letothers know the situation.
Makerware seems to do better for me than RepG on support.
Generally I try to model without supports but sometimes I just want the model a way that support-free printing
won't allow.
if you have used the soluable support, let me know your experiences. I have heard very few reports,
but most were not glowing recomendations.

author: Neirbonhoj

title: Print Flat - Roll Into 3D, Heptagonal Column

description.text: Had an idea for a way to print something flat, but then fold it up into the intended 3D shape. Should work well with anything conical/column-like, including, say, wings! EDIT: I made a wing using this technique, which I've take to calling Flat-Roll... Here it is: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:483 (I kinda forgot to make it a derivative of this one, not used to that feature working again) This rests on the notion (or hope?) that if you print something sufficiently thin, it will bend without snapping. (Might need to heat the piece?) If this is true, you can split your 3D shape into flat sections and unroll it, print it, and then roll it back up. This may not be the best way to do this, but I connected each section in this first experiment with just a face, no thickness... I'm hoping Skeinforge will automatically print that with the thinnest layer it can, but I don't really know. EDIT2: Nophead returned some experience and pointed out that zero-thickness faces won't print at all. Luckily, this is easily fixable since that big, flat underside is easily adjustable with a push-pull or extrude command in most CAD programs. Here's a variation that shows this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:485 EDIT3: Jay Swift pointed out that you could print this out onto a sheet of flexible plastic without adjusting the thickness at all. You would then trim the sheet prior to rolling the whole thing up. If this is workable, future improvements would include centering pins on the contact faces between each section... perhaps even some kind of latching mechanism.

Once printed, this piece should be rollable into a heptagonal column, as per the screenshots from Sketchup.
By the way, I confirm Sketchup has all the required snap tools ;-)
Oh, and just as an FYI for those who don't know, the easy/free way to get a model from Sketchup into Blender: export as a Google Earth object, change the extension of the saved file to .zip, open the archive, retrieve the .dae file in the 'models' subdir and import that into Blender using the 'import Collada 1.4' option.

comments.text: The no thickness face will not print. The slicers sample at Z equal to the middle of each layer. So unfortunately to guarantee a one layer surface you need to know the layer height.
comments.author: nophead

comments.text: As pointed out elsewhere by Jay Swift, you could also print it out, still at zero thickness, on a sheet of flexible plastic. You would only need to trim the sheet before rolling it up.
comments.author: nophead

remixed_from.author: cfeniak
remixed_from.title: Direct Drive Bowden Extruder; MK8 version

description.text: Accessory for the extruder I designed.  Mount to the lower M3 holes (10mm spacing).  Put a foam piece on the inside to clean dust off your filament before it enters the bowden tube, or add canola oil to the foam to slowly lubricate and continuously season an all metal hotend for use with PLA.  The long latch gives the plastic enough flexibility to open and close without breaking.  Slots at the top allow for oil addition.  Print in place hinge allows the container to pivot for alignment but also be moved out of the way if switching to ABS.

I printed mine is ABS as it is less brittle / more plastic.  Hopefully it will work in PLA as well but I haven't tried it.  Make sure you don't over extrude or the hinge will fuse.  If this is a problem then turn down your flow rate a percent or two.  Also make sure you have adequate cooling if printing fast in PLA.  No need for any support.  0.2mm layers are fine, I don't see any benefit to going lower for this item.

title: Star Lord's Boot Jets from Guardians of the Galaxy

description.text:
No Peter Quill Cosplay would be complete without boot jets! These were done in 123 Design (not my best work, but pretty accurate). This is a work in progress. As soon as I print the other set, I'll assemble, paint, then add more pictures of the finished pieces. Hope you enjoy.
UPDATE: 10/4/14
Finally finished painting! I've attached pictures of the finished pieces. We decided to go with a Velcro strap around the ankle to hold them on because of the zipper placement of the leg chaps my son used which didn't provide a good hold for stick on Velcro. Also, be careful with the joining of the upper and lower jet halves. I super glued them and had one break apart on me while painting. I re-glued with acetone (since they were ABS) then drilled and drove a small screw at an angle through the bottom half up into the upper half of the jet. I put it in the back, so you won't see it. The two pieces should be redesigned to have a peg or raised area that fits into the other half. If your printer can handle the height, the best option would be to combine the two halves into one piece...

I split the model into separate pieces to make it as versatile for printing as possible. I printed in ABS and plan to glue the top and bottom jets together, then glue to the middle section. The jet tops have counter-bored holes for attaching screws. These are recommended to add structural support for the jets as well as to provide cosmetic treatment. Pre-drill the holes into the middle section and use #6x3/4" or similar screws.
For attaching the unit to your boot, I included a slot in the middle section to run a strap/velcro. I'm going to try and use stick-on velcro panels across the back of the middle section and to the boot itself. There should be enough surface there to provide sufficient adhesion and I won't have a strap showing...
I printed each piece with 5% infill and 3 shells at .27 layer height. I tried to reduce the weight in the models as much as possible. Hope you enjoy and post pictures if you make these.

description.text:
This is a tool that combined with a standard single-edge 39x19mm razor blade can rapidly and safely slice a Coroplast sheet centered in the extrusion flute. Created for use building my heat recovery ventilator project at http://hackaday.io/project/2517-Entropy-Wheel-Heat-Recovery-Ventilator.
*** NEW Arrival: the cross-cut blade. Made for cutting "across the grain". Still printing first draft to test.

Sketched in Visio to get a 2D concept, then rendered in OpenSCAD. Will add OpenSCAD code when firmed up.
You will need to rotate it to sit upright on its back, flat edge to print without support. Use high resolution settings. You will need a raft to prevent wobble from ruining your print. Hopefully the 0.41mm slot will print open without closing up. Blades are only 0.25mm thick, so it is challenge.
Added some things: stabilizers that snap off after printing. Also recommend 25% infill, 2 shells, 220C with ABS to print, and PRINT TWO COPIES AT ONCE OR ONE CROSSCUT GUIDE WITH IT.
The design is small so it doesn't cool fast enough when printed alone. Use a raft. Razor slot is tight but the 0.25mm thick blade cuts through the slag with a little push. Pretty tight to cut but guidance is perfect.

description.text:
My quadruped is a 3D printable robot that will be upgradable to an unlimited amount of legs (as long as you have the electronics to control it) I wanted a robot that I could build expand when I wanted I am currently getting this robot printed by a friend  I have had low quality parts made quickly to test fit certain parts. I will control the quadruped with lynxmotions BotBoarduino and the SSC-32 Servo Controller (mounting brackets to come) with Bluetooth control and ps3 controler with 12 tower pro sg5010 servos to start with due to cost but will upgrade servos to something better please bare with me I will supply instruction soon as I make it. i am working on the extra leg version now will post them soon as well as other add ons.
Everything has been designed to be printed on a standard print bed.
Pictures will be added as soon as the servos decide to turn up .
remember I have made this for you to make so don't be afraid to ask for changes Constructive criticism very welcome (but don't abuse it)

OK here goes bear with me this is my first time with instructions like this so i will break it down into segments.

  • the feet are made up of 5 sections each 2x foot sides, 1x foot support short, 1 foot support long and 1x toe look at the foot picture for guidance. my plan was to use an m2 tap and m2x8 countersunk screws to make it look nice and neat but you can use self tappers you may need to drill the holes a bit bigger to avoid splitting. im planning on using the toes with pressure sensors mounted in the feet to allow it to feel but for now it will be fixed.

  • the Femur/legs made up of 3 parts 1x leg and 2x pin there may be another part to the pin soon a sort of cap that screws on just need servos to turn up to make sure sizes are right i may even get rid of the pin a print the leg as one piece the pins fix onto the leg in-line with the servo horn to act as a pivot see the leg assembled picture.

comments.text: The Spider Controller will handle 48 standard servos as well. You just can't POWER them all from the board. If you connect the servos to a separate power source, and the signal line to the Spider Controller, you will be fine. As was mentioned already, keep on eye on the current required to supply to all the servos and plan accordingly. A couple/few UBECs should do it depending on how many legs you are going for (look for the ones that can switch to 6v to get the most power to your servos). I'll leave a link to more information, you can catch the designer here from time to time if you have more questions about it. :) http://letsmakerobots.com/node/26054http://letsmakerobots.com/node...
comments.author: trev502000

comments.text:
Hey there, just thought I'd clarify some stuff about that board. The reason that it says 48 micro servos is because it has a 3A MAX current limit on the board. I'm not sure what the stall current is on your Tower Pro's, but most standard sized servos have a stall current of about 1-1.5A. This means that if say, the first two legs got stuck and drew 2 amps, plus the current of the other servos, it could break your board. The SSC-32 is rated for 30A and is more than capable. If you are looking for a slightly cheaper board that can be daisy-chained easily, you might want to check out the Pololu Mini-Maestro's. They have a nifty computer application for controlling them too.
Also, nice project! I really wish I had a 3D printer so I could try it!

description.text: One more sponge-box for Replicator 2!!!!

As Valentine's day approach, i thought i would post this thing i did a while ago. 3 parts for it (hot-glued together post-print):
-the lips
-the top-plate
-the back plate and one additional part:
-the color change plug I strongly suggest to first make some quick ugly trials, as you will have to play around a bit with the scales. As for the color change plug, i use it to help me to see when i need to change the filament.
I place it at the lower left corner of the plate.
Once you see that, for example, the names start to be printed, wait for the printer to go to the plug. once there, press the "Change filament" button on the Rep2. Change your filament, and normally, it will restart on the plug, and the couple of printing path there will suffice to make sure the plastic flows back to normal, ensuring some nice, pretty different color name printing. Note:
the lips are a "cut" from BebemeMucho (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13048)

Wisdom Daruma

As I went to open my blind in my bedroom one fine day, the left bracket exploded and the blind fell on my head.  These are the cheap, Walmart style blinds that were never really designed to last, I imagine, but in any case, it seemed stupid to buy new blinds than to just make a new cap.  So this is that.

Print and mount.  That's it.  Bots that are better calibrated will naturally yield better prints, but mine did pretty darned good nonetheless.  Item of note -- the cap that fits into place to keep the blind in place is a little tight.  It works and holds, but the bracket flexes open just a tiny bit.  If you know the secret, then by jove, tell everyone.
Oh yeah, that's a Google Sketchup file there with the two parts in it.  Edit to your hearts content.

description.text:
MakerBot employee Johnathan Cook suggested embedding recycling symbols into the things we print. I think this is a really cool idea. I was able to take Johnathan's original JPG, trace it into an SVG in Inkscape, export to DXF files for cutting, and then extrude into a printable STL in OpenSCAD. I've attached a file with each of these intermediary filetypes. If someone wanted, they could now add one of these symbols sticking out from their object or cut out from their object to leave this impression. Each of the STL files indicates the approximate dimensions of the recycling symbol. abs-70x90x10.stl
This file produces an ABS recycling symbol of approximately 70x90x10mm. pla-70x90x10.stl
This file produces a PLA recycling symbol of approximately 70x90x10mm. symbol-70x70x10.stl
This file produces a recycling symbol of approximately 70x70x10mm.

• Add a blank recycling symbol, an ABS recycling symbol, or a PLA recycling symbol to your printable objects!
  • Use
  • Recycle
  • GOTO 1

A little rocketship that I modeled in SolidWorks instead of doing "real work".

Print it, paint it, make blast-off noises and fly it around the room.  Or print it in white and stick an LED in it to make a lamp.  I may have to print some of these to put on the X-mas tree now that I think of it.

Just in time for Halloween!
This little lantern uses an inexpensive battery operated LED "Tea Light" candle that can be purchased at most craft stores or on-line. (I paid $1.99 for one at the local craft store.) The tea light is mounted upside down in the top of the lantern.
The handle is optional. You don't need if you aren't going to hang the lantern.

The "Face Panels" should be printed with a translucent plastic such as natural PLA.
Attach the bones to the corners of the lantern with glue.
The face panels slide into groves on the inside of the lantern and the light support goes on top as shown in the exploded photo. These parts can be secured with a couple drops of glue if desired.

description.text:
My nephew really likes dinosaurs, so for his upcoming birthday I remixed him a dino-shaped piggybank...
I sliced it in three so it fits on my Kossel bed (200mm), just used plastic glue for putting it together.
Thanks to faulty for pointing me to the original source: ErikHK's dinosaur - I hollowed it out and added the top slot as well as the breakable hole at the bottom.

Can be printed in one piece, without supports.
For printing on a Kossel 170mm bed, resize to 85%. No supports needed.
Walls are about 1.5mm wide.

author: ifihadtime

title: Stepper upgrade for makerbot MK5 extruder

description.text: An adapter for the Makerbot Mk5 extruder for a stepper motor

This uses a modified version of Wade's gears derived from Nicolas's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4305 Build the adapter part and one each of the gears. Drill out the holes in the adaptor with a 3mm drill, the holes on the wider side are larger and are to accommodate the heads of the bolts if you clear that side of the holes be careful not to drill all the way through. Sand the top surface of the adaptor flat - it will seat on the Mk5 where the existing motor does. The large gear is used upside down from the way that Wade uses it the bolt goes in from the flat side with gear's hub pointing to the thread end. Here we will use a novel tool, it appears one can't just add ones own tools to Thingiverse - I'd like to introduce FIRE, a versatile and old-school tool - it may be obtained variously from Prometheus, MÄtariÅ›van, Coyote, Rabbit, MÄui etc or their proxies, it may also be stolen from the gods directly, though the whole standing in a storm with a kite thing is not recommended - I just use the stove. Rather than moulding a hex hole in the gear the head of the M6 bolt is melted in to the flat surface of the gear as a build step: take the bolt in a pair of vice grips as a heat sink, heat the head on a stove or other flame - when it's just hot enough to melt some scrap ABS quickly drop the bolt through the hole and pull it until it's embedded in the gear, gently spin the bolt and align the gear so that it's true before the bolt cools. Use your fire again in a different form to fit the M3 nut into the square hole at the base of the small gear - if it wont fit, get a soldering iron, heat it and use it to push the nut into the hole until it lines up correctly. Attach the M3x8mm bolt grub screw to the small gear. Take the stepper motor, file one side of the drive shaft flat (use blue tack to keep filings out of the motor bearing). Place the small gear on the drive shaft, don't completely tighten the grub screw, attach the motor to the slots in the adapter using the 4 M3 12mm bolts/M4 washers (gear side down) don't tighten them yet. Place bearings in each end of the adapter - the lower one should be flush, the upper one sits in a 1mm lip and should extend 5mm. Place a washer on the bolt on the gear and drop the bolt through the bearings (you might temporarily put a nut/washers on the end to hold the lower bearing in place. Adjust the position of the motor and tighten the two visible bolts also adjust the position of the small gear and tighten the grub screw (make sure it can turn without binding). Remove the large gear/bolt/washer, tighten the other two motor retaining bolts. Also slide the 4 m3x35mm bolts into their holes. Replace the large gear/bolt/washer. Now start to disassemble the Mk5 - first run the Z stage up as high as you can go, and remove any filament, there's no reason to remove everything from the makerbot - first remove the 4 bolts that hold the motor, remove the motor - leave the 606 bearing in place Remove the Mk5 Drive gear from the old motor, disconnect the motor from extruder controller and put it aside. Slide the Mk5 Drive Gear onto the end of the M6 bolt on the adapter (grubs screw end first just like it was on the motor) put it up close to the bearing, gently tighten the grub screw - at some point the grub screw will seat between 2 threads on the bolt, turn the drive gear so that it screws down the thread as close as it can go to the bearing without binding, tighten the grub screw. Look at the extruder - there are 4 m3 bolts equidistant around the hole the motor came out of - remove all 4, keep the nuts. Now place the adapter into the position where the motor was, the stepper motor should be oriented towards the electronics end of the Makerbot - slide the bolt in through the hole the old motor came from and out the other side through the 606 bearing you left in place - the bearing that protrudes 5mm from the adapter should be sitting in the extruder and the drive gear should be back where it originally came from. You can put a nut/washer on the end of the bolt if you want but it's really not needed, that bearing has been sitting there comfortably by itself for a while now. The 4 35mm bolts should now be extending through the holes you removed the last set of bolts from - use the 4 nuts you saved to tighten them up to hold down the new adapter nice and tight. Hook up the stepper motor - I used a Makerbot stepper - it has 4 wires (their colors may vary for other steppers) - they're connected to a normal stepper board as A/B/C/D we're going to connect them to the extruder board's H-bridge outputs 1A/1B/2A/2B as follows: Color stepper extruder yellow A 1A red B 1B black C 2A orange D 2B Now we're ready to turn things on - directions are from the following: http://wiki.makerbot.com/stepper-driven-extruder Run repg and choose Machine->upload new firmware->extruder controller->v2.3 release 3 w/stepper support. Do the usual extruder firmware upgrade dance. Quit from repg and edit your 'machines.xml' file (lives in ~/.replicatorg on Linux, elsewhere for other systems) find the section that describes your machine and look for the following <tool name="Pinch Wheel Extruder .... line - add 'motor_steps="400"' to the end of it, it will look something like: Restart repg - when you restart (and every time after that you'll get a warning that you could upgrade, ignore it. Go into the control panel - choose "140" for the PWM and "10" for the "RPM" without any plastic in place press 'forward' - does it go forwards? 'reverse' does it go reverse? if so you're OK, otherwise you may need to switch some of your wires until it does. To set up skeinforge you need to install 'rpmify' use this link for < v31 http://groups.google.com/group/makerbot/msg/4bb1aad2edbaec22 and this one for sf version 31+ http://groups.google.com/group/makergear/msg/156e78cc56098c27 (I've only tested the last one) the instructions don't say but you should copy the script to skeinforge_application/skeinforge_plugins/craft_plugins. Edit your skeinforge settings, go into the new 'rpmify' page and enable it, on the 'speed' page the 'flow rate' now represents the RPM x10. Having said all this I've pretty much convinced myself that having followed the instructions above the RPM and PWM end up backwards

title: Rep2 spool holder for FormFutura reels.

My first pcb with eagle. Board is not tested (may do so later when I have access to prototyping equipment). A very compact arduino with robotics and wireless communication in mind. Designed to be used with servos, HopeRF TR-HM transceiver, and DFRobot motor driver. Two voltage regulators on board (second one dedicated to servos and powered when VR2 jumper is connected).
Standard resistor values and capacitor values apply. Choose 680Ohm for R1 and R2, 10k for R3. C1, C2, and C3 are 100uF while C4 and C5 are 100nF.

This tile set has been superseded by the much improved OpenForge 2.0 Tudor set. That set is both more complete, and vastly better designed, please, check it out. OpenForge
=========
Tudor style corridor tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    Changelog
    =========
    9/27/2014 - Found a new way to do wood that results in better/simpler models. Regenerated using that technique.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.

Printed in black. Dry brushed with dark brown and then used ever lighter shades in the dry brush. To lighten, used a light leather, not a white in order to get more yellow in the highlights.
The walls were painted in white, then mixed with the leather color, finally I stippled the walls with white again using a toothbrush.
Keychain accessory for the technology startup incubator, the Zahn Center NYC
It's not a very complicated thing; just a single part and not too big. Print with higher detail and more slowly to get a better piece.
This is fan duct to fit 25mm fan to cool down J-head MK V.

Just some Windows... quick&dirty like the spoolholder this morning ;-)
I made this alignemnt target to help set the offest of my dual head machine in Slic3r or Marlin.

• Mesure and set Firmware of slicer for offest of your dual head printer.
  • Merge pieces in your favorite slicer.
  • Print part
  • Note any gaps/overlap between arrows and target. Boxes on outside help mesurments with calipers.
  • Adjust Offsets and print again untill perfect alignment. (Or close as you can get...)
  • Print many other dual colour things for fun! :)

Please print it in yellow(or similar color) to support us!
DO NOT print in BLUE! Please also see
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:486819

Fight for Democracy!  
Support Hong Kong's Umbrella Revolution

Brief introduction of umbrella revolution (from wiki): In September 2014, pro-democracy campaigners in Hong Kong protested outside the government headquarters and occupied several major throughfares to protest against the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress' decision on proposed electoral reform which ruled out genuine democracy for the forthcoming 2017 Hong Kong Chief Executive election. The name Umbrella Revolution was possibly first used by Twitter user @Aureliano_no_24 on September 26 to describe the Hong Kong protest and has been used by many sources since a large number of protestors used umbrellas to defend themselves from pepper spray and tear gas.[2][3][4][5][6]
Student groups Hong Kong Federation of Students and Scholarism began protesting outside the government headquarters in the week of 22 September 2014.[7] In the evening of 26 September, a group of several hundred demonstrators breached a security barrier and entered the plaza in front of the Central Government Complex, which has been barred from public entry since 2014 following "security concerns". They soon were cordoned off by police and blockaded overnight, which caused more protestors to join the protest and surround the police. This led to a stand-off which lasted over a day, during which police attacked unarmed protesters with shields, batons, and pepper spray. Occupy Central with Love and Peace announced that they would begin their civil disobedience campaign with immediate effect.[8]
Around noon on 28 September, protesters spilled onto Harcourt Road and proceeded to occupy Queensway as well, blocking both east-west arterial routes on northern Hong Kong Island. After several hours of stand-off, police dispersed the crowds with tear gas and water cannons, and threatened to open fire with rubber bullets if crowds did not leave the scene.
More on NBC News:
http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/hong-kong-protests/hong-kong-protests-spread-umbrella-revolution-takes-hold-n213771
